The extensive explanation of causes is finished.
What is the condition again?
Verse:
It is said there are four kinds of conditions, the causal condition has the nature of five causes,
The immediately preceding is not after, the mind and mental factors have already arisen,
The object is all dharmas, the dominant is the able to act.
Discussion:
Where is it said?
It is said in the sÅ«tras.
It is said in the sÅ«tras that there are four kinds of conditional natures, namely the causal condition, the immediately preceding condition, the object condition, and the dominant condition.
Here, nature refers to the type of condition.
Among the six causes, excluding the efficient cause, the remaining five causes are the causal condition.
Except for the last mind and mental factors of an arhat at the time of entering nirvÄá¹‡a, all other arisen mind and mental factors are the immediately preceding condition.

The meaning of the term â€œsimilar and immediately antecedent conditionâ€ is established on the basis of this principle of dependent origination, namely, that these dharmas of dependent origination are similar and without interval.
For this reason, form, etc., cannot be established as similar and immediately antecedent conditions, because they are not born in the same way.

That is, form of the realm of desire is sometimes immediately followed by the arising of two kinds of form of the realm of desire and the realm of form, or it is immediately followed by the arising of two kinds of pure form of the realm of desire.

Because the manifestation of form dharmas is confused, and the similar and immediately antecedent condition is not confused, therefore form is not established as a similar and immediately antecedent condition.
Bhadanta Vasumitra says that

in a single body, the continuity of one kind of form that is nourished is not interrupted, and there is a second kind of form that is nourished that is born, and they do not conflict with each other, and therefore they cannot be established as similar and immediately antecedent conditions.
The Bhadanta says that

the arising of form dharmas without interval is sometimes small and sometimes large. That is, sometimes many are born from a small number, as when a large mass of rice stalks is burned and reduced to ashes.

Sometimes there is also birth of many from few, as when a small seed produces a nyagrodha tree, with its roots, trunk, branches, and leaves gradually increasing and flourishing, with its trunk rising and its branches hanging down, shading a great many things.
Isn't it the case that when mental activities are born without interval, there are also few and many kinds that are not equal?

That is, in good, bad, and indeterminate minds, there are applied thought, sustained thought, samÄdhi, etc. Although there are indeed few and many in different kinds, there is no meaning of inequality within the same kind. That is, there is no birth of many from few without interval, or birth of few from many without interval. Ideas, etc. are also like this, with no error of inequality.
Isn't it only the same kind that can be the immediately antecedent condition for the subsequent?ğŸ”½No.
How is it?
The dharmas of the preceding class of mind are generally the immediately antecedent condition for the subsequent class, not only of the same kind.
As for the same kind of feeling, etc., there is no birth of many from few, because it is said to be equal.

This is said by those who maintain that only similar and immediately antecedent dharmas are conditions as the equivalent and immediate antecedent. Mind only produces mind, feeling only produces feeling, and so on at length.

If immediately after a nondefiled state a defiled state arises, the defilements present in this defiled state take as their condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent the defilements that have just ceased.

This is like the case of emerging from the concentration of cessation, where the mind that has just ceased when one enters the concentration of cessation is the condition for the arising of the mind that emerges from the concentration of cessation.
This explanation is not good, because the first pure mind would lack this condition and be able to be born.
Nonassociated dharmas are also like form, in that they are confused and present. Therefore they are not conditions as the equivalent and immediate antecedent.
The three realms and the unconditioned can be present simultaneously. Why do you not admit that conditions as the equivalent and immediate antecedent exist in the future?
Because future dharmas are confused and do not have a sequence of prior and posterior.
How does the World Honored One know that this dharma immediately after that dharma should be born in the future?
He knows this through inference from dharmas of the present and past.
The Buddha saw that from such and such past actions such and such results were born, and that such and such dharmas are born immediately after such dharmas.
Also, from such and such present actions such and such results are born, and that such and such dharmas are born immediately after such and such dharmas.
Having seen this, he then correctly understood that from such and such dharmas in the future such and such dharmas are born immediately after them.
Even though he knows this, it is not inferential knowledge.

Because the Buddha infers the sequence of causes and effects in the past and present, he is able to understand clearly the dharmas in the future that are not in a state of immediate sequence. He knows that in the future such and such sentient beings will create such and such actions and attract such and such results. This is knowledge of vows and therefore not inferential knowledge.
If this is so, then the Buddha, not having seen the prior limit, would be unable to know dharmas of the later limit.
Other masters say:
In the body of sentient beings there is a prior indication of the cause of future results. This is a species of the aggregate of mental dharmas that are not associated with mind.
The Buddha observes only this and then knows the future, not necessarily by means of the samÄdhi of the supernormal knowledge of the present.
If this is so, then the buddhas would know the future by divination, not by direct perception.
Therefore, as the masters of the SautrÄntika school say, the World-Honored One knows all dharmas by raising his mind, not by inference or divination.
This explanation is good.
As the World-Honored One said:
The virtues and functions of the buddhas, and the realm of the buddhas, are inconceivable.

If there is no definite sequential arrangement of past, present, and future, then why is it said that only the supreme worldly dharmas immediately give rise to the forbearance of the dharma of suffering, and not other dharmas?
In this way, it is explained in detail up to the vajra-like samÄdhi immediately giving rise to the knowledge of exhaustion, and not other dharmas.
If the arising of this dharma is dependent on that dharma, then it can only arise immediately after that, just as sprouts and so forth arise only by relying on seeds and so forth.
However, this does not have an equal and immediately antecedent condition.
Why is it said that the final mind and mental activities of arhats are not conditions as cause?
Because no other mind or mental activities arise in a series from them.
Why is the mind that has just ceased not called manas?ğŸ”½Because the subsequent mind does not arise from it. Manas is revealed as a support, not as a function.
The final mind has the meaning of a support, but a subsequent mind does not arise because other conditions are lacking. The condition as cause is revealed as a function.

If a dharma is grasped as a result by this condition, then no dharma or sentient being can obstruct it and prevent its arising. Therefore, although the final mind is called manas, it cannot be said to be a condition as cause.
If a dharma is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent for mind, is it also an antecedent of mind?
Four sentences are possible.
The first is the mind and mental activities that emerge from the two mindless samÄdhis and the second moment of the two samÄdhis.
The second phrase refers to the arising, abiding, and cessation of the first moment of the two meditative attainments and of the mind and mental factors in the state with mind.
The third phrase refers to the first moment of the two meditative attainments and the mind and mental factors in the state with mind.
The fourth phrase refers to the second moment of the two meditative attainments and the arising, abiding, and cessation of the mind and mental factors upon emerging from the attainment without mind.
If a dharma is a similar and immediately antecedent condition for mind, is it also an immediately antecedent condition for the attainment without mind?
Four sentences should be made.

That is, the third and fourth sentences of the previous [analysis] are the first and second sentences of the present [analysis], and the first and second sentences of the previous [analysis] are the third and fourth sentences of the present [analysis].

The mind and mental factors upon emerging from the two meditative attainments are separated by a long interval from the mind entering the meditative attainment. How can they be the similar and immediately antecedent condition for that [mind]?
Because they are not separated by any mind or mental factors in the interval.
Thus the similar and immediately antecedent condition has been explained.
The nature of the condition as object is that all dharmas are the condition as object for mind and mental activities, according to the case.
That is, eye consciousness and mental activities take all forms as the condition as object.
In the same way, ear consciousness and mental activities take all sounds.ğŸ”½Nose consciousness and mental activities take all smells.
Tongue consciousness and mental activities take all tastes.
Body consciousness and mental activities take all tangibles.
Mental consciousness and mental activities take all dharmas as the condition as object.

When a dharma is the object of another dharma, it is never not the condition as object for it. Even in a state when it is not being perceived, it is still categorized as the condition as object, because the nature of the object is the same whether it is being perceived or not.
It is like fuel, etc., which, even when not burning, is still called combustible, because its nature is the same.
Are mind and its activities as definitely determined in regard to their support as they are in regard to their objects, locations, and moments?
It should be said that there is also such a determination, but in the present it is closely related to its own support, while in the past and future it is separated from its support.
Some say:
In the past it is also closely related to its support.
Thus the nature of the condition as object has been explained.
The nature of the dominant condition is the efficient cause, because the efficient cause is the dominant condition.
This condition is called the dominant condition because its substance is extensive, because all are dominant conditions.
Since all dharmas are also conditions as objects, why is only this dominant condition extensive in substance?
Coexistent dharmas are never objects, but they are dominant, and therefore only this is extensive in substance.
Or, it is called the dominant condition because its function is extensive, because all dharmas, excluding their own substance, are dominant conditions for all conditioned dharmas.
Can there be a dharma that is not a condition in any of the four ways for a certain dharma?
There can be, namely, oneâ€™s own nature for oneâ€™s own nature, and also for the natures of others.
That is, the conditioned [dharmas] with regard to the unconditioned, and the unconditioned [dharmas] with regard to the unconditioned.
In what state do these conditions give rise to their activity?
The verse states:
The two causes [of co-existent and associated causes] are in the present state of cessation, and the three causes [of homogeneous, pervasive, and ripening causes] are in the present state of birth.
The remaining two [conditions of condition as cause and condition as object] are contrary to this, and give rise to their activity.
The treatise states:
The previously mentioned five causes are the nature of causal conditions. The activity of the two causes [of co-existent and associated causes] is in the present state of cessation.
The phrase present state of cessation indicates that dharmas are in the present. Because cessation is present, it is called the present state of cessation.
The two causes [of co-existent and associated causes] give rise to their activity in the state of cessation of dharmas. This is because these two causes cause the co-arisen fruits to have activity.

As for the statement that the three causes are in the present state of birth, it means that future dharmas in the state of birth are about to be born, and are therefore called the present state of birth.
The three kinds of [homogeneous, pervasive, and ripening] causes give rise to their activity in the state of birth of dharmas.

The two conditions of cause and condition as direct antecedent have already been explained as having activity at two times. The two conditions of object and condition as dominant are the opposite of this.
The condition as equal and immediate antecedent has activity at the time the dharma arises, because when it arises, the prior mind and mental activities provide a place for it.
If the condition as object has activity at the time the condition is extinguished, because mind and mental activities must grasp an object in the present.
Only the condition as dominant has no obstruction at all times, and therefore its activity is not obstructed at any time.
The activity of the four conditions has already been explained.
How many conditions produce what dharmas?
The verse says:
Mind and mental activities are produced by four conditions. The two mindless samÄdhis are produced by three.
The remaining dharmas are produced by two conditions, not by the condition as cause, etc.
The treatise says:
Mind and mental activities are produced by four conditions. Among them, the condition as cause is the five kinds of causes.
The condition as equal and immediate antecedent is the prior mind and mental activities that have already arisen and are not the subsequent mind and mental activities.
As for the condition as object, it is the five sense objects such as form, or all dharmas, as appropriate.
As for the dominant condition, it is all dharmas, excluding their own nature, as appropriate.
The two samÄdhis of cessation and non-perception are produced by three conditions, excluding the condition as object, because they do not grasp objects.
As for the causal condition, it is produced by two causes:
first, the co-existent cause, which is the characteristics of birth, etc.;
second, the homogeneous cause, which is the wholesome dharmas of the same stage that have already arisen.
The condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent is the mind and mental factors that enter samÄdhi.
The dominant condition is as explained above.

Thus, the mind of these two samÄdhis is produced by samÄdhi, and because it obstructs the arising of mind, it is equivalent to mind, but it is only the equivalent and immediate antecedent, not the condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent.
The other dharmas not associated with mind and all material forms are produced by the two conditions of cause and dominant.
All things in the world arise from the above-mentioned causes and conditions, not from a single cause such as the self, God, or prakriti. What is the reason for this?
If you admit that all things are produced by causes, why not abandon the theory that all things in the world are produced by a single cause such as God?
Also, things in the world are not produced by a single cause such as God, because of sequence, etc.
If things in the world were produced by a single cause such as God, then all things would be produced simultaneously and not arise in sequence.
But we see that things arise in sequence, so we know that they are definitely not produced by a single cause.

If you insist that God produces things according to his desires, that is, he desires that this thing should arise now, that thing should cease now, and this thing should arise later, then it would not be produced by a single cause, because it arises from the difference in desires.
Or, the different desires would arise simultaneously, because the cause, God, is without difference.
If you say that distinctions in desire must await other causes and do not occur simultaneously, then not all things have as their cause a single substance that is the cause of all.
Or else, the causes that are awaited must also await other causes in order to arise in sequence, and then the causes that are awaited would have no limit.
If they do not await other causes in order to arise in sequence, then these causes would not have the meaning of arising in sequence, and then distinctions in desire would not arise in sequence.

If you admit that the distinctions in causes are without limit, because you believe in beginninglessness, then in vain you hold that God is the cause of dharmas, but you do not go beyond the correct principle of causation of the Buddhists.
If you say that although the desires of God arise suddenly, the world does not arise simultaneously because it arises in accordance with the desires of God, this is not reasonable.
Because the prior state of Gods desires is no different from the subsequent state.
Moreover, what benefit does God gain by making great effort to create the world?

If he generates the various worlds in order to generate joy, this joy is not generated apart from other conditions. In that case, he is not sovereign in generating joy, since he must depend on other conditions.
Just as it is with joy, so it is with the other feelings. No reason can be found for any difference among them.
If the sovereign generates hell beings and other such beings who are tormented by innumerable sufferings, he generates joy at the sight of this.
Alas!
What use is such a sovereign?
The verse of the treatise states this well.
Because of being sharp, burning, fearful, and constantly harming,
and because of enjoying eating blood, flesh, and marrow, he is called Rudra.

Moreover, if one believes and accepts that the entire world arises from only one cause, the sovereign god, then one would deny the presently seen other causes and conditions in the world, such as human effort.

If it is said that God, in dependence on other conditions that assist in the development of his power, becomes a cause, this is merely a statement of respect for God. Apart from other conditions, we do not see any separate function of God.
Or, if God must be assisted by other conditions in order to generate, he is not God.

If it is held that the initial creation is caused by God, and that subsequent continuation is dependent on other causes, then the initial creation, not depending on other causes, would be uncaused and eternal, just like God.
Self, supreme principle, etc., as appropriate, should be extensively refuted like God. Therefore, there is no dharma that is produced by a single cause.
How strange that the world does not cultivate wisdom, like foolish animals, it is truly lamentable.
In each rebirth, one creates karma separately and experiences the results of retribution and the results of human effort, yet falsely imagines that there is a cause such as God.
Let us stop refuting wrong views for now and discuss the correct meaning.
Previously it was said that other dharmas are born from two conditions. In this, how do the great elements and the derivative form mutually serve as causal conditions for each other?
The verse says:
The great elements are the two causes for the great elements, and are the five kinds for the derivative form.
The derivative form is the three kinds for the derivative form, and is the one cause for the great elements.
The treatise says:
The first sentence the great elements are the two causes for the great elements means that the great elements mutually serve as co-existent causes and homogeneous causes for each other.
The great elements are able to be the five causes for the derivative form.
What are the five?
They are the causes of birth, support, establishment, maintenance, and nourishment.
These five causes are only the distinctions of the enabling cause.
Because they arise from them, they are called the causes of birth. Because after arising they follow and transform according to the great elements,
like relying on a teacher, etc., they are called the causes of support. Because they are able to uphold,
like a wall holding up a painting, they are called the causes of establishment.
Because they are the uninterrupted causes, they are called the causes of maintenance.
It is called the cause of nourishment because it is the cause of growth.
Thus it is shown that the great elements are the cause of arising, transformation, support, duration, and growth of the derivative form.
The derivative form has three causes in relation to each other, namely, coexistent cause, similar cause, and retributive cause.
The efficient cause is not always counted because it operates without distinction.
The coexistent cause refers to the two kinds of karma of body and speech that accompany the mind, not the other derivative form.
The similar cause refers to all that has arisen previously in relation to that which is similar later.
The retributive cause refers to the eye faculty, etc., which are the results of the retribution of the two kinds of karma of body and speech.
Derivative form is only one cause in relation to the great elements, namely, the retributive cause.
This is because the two kinds of karma of body and speech are able to attract the great elements as their results of retribution.

Previously it was said in general that the mind and mental factors of the present moment can be the similar and immediately antecedent condition for those of the future. It has not yet been determined which mind arises immediately after how many minds, and from how many minds what kind of mind arises.
Now I will explain definitively. It is said that there are twelve minds in brief.
What are the twelve?
The verse says:
There are four minds in the desire realm: wholesome, unwholesome, obscured, and unobscured.
The form and formless realms exclude the unwholesome, and the uncontaminated have two minds.
The treatise says:
In the desire realm there are four kinds of minds, namely wholesome, unwholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral.
The form and formless realms each have three minds, excluding the unwholesome, the rest being as explained above.
These ten kinds are said to be contaminated minds.
If the uncontaminated mind has only two kinds, namely learner and post-learner.
Combined, they form twelve.
As for the mutual arising of these twelve minds, the verse says:
The wholesome mind of the desire realm gives rise to nine, and it arises from eight in turn;
The defiled mind gives rise to four from ten, and the other arises from seven from five;
The wholesome mind of the form realm gives rise to eleven, and it arises from nine in turn;
The obscured [mind] arises from eight [minds], and it in turn produces six [minds].
The non-obscured [mind] arises from three [minds], and it in turn can produce six [minds].
The wholesome [mind] of the formless realm produces nine [minds], and it in turn arises from six [minds].
The obscured [mind] arises from seven [minds], and the non-obscured [mind] is explained like the form realm.
The learner [mind] arises from four [minds], and the other [mind] arises from five [minds].
The treatise says:
The wholesome mind of the desire realm immediately produces nine [minds], namely the four of its own realm;
the two minds of the form realm, when entering concentration and at the time of rebirth, produce the wholesome and defiled minds in order;
and the one of the formless realm, at the time of rebirth.
The defiled mind of the formless realm immediately produces the wholesome mind of the desire realm, but does not produce its wholesome mind because it is too far away.
The formless realm is far from the desire realm for four reasons:
one, the basis is far; two, the aspects are far; three, the objects are far; four, the antidotes are far.
And the learner and post-learner [minds], when entering into concentration.
It arises immediately after eight, that is, four of its own realm, and the two minds of the form realm, when one emerges from samÄdhi, it arises from that good mind.
When oppressed by the defiled samÄdhi, it arises from that defiled mind in the lower realm, because it relies on the good mind of the lower realm to prevent its regression.
And from the two pure minds, when one emerges from samÄdhi.
Defiled means unwholesome and obscured-neutral. Each arises immediately after ten, excluding the two pure minds, in the state of rebirth.
The minds of the three realms can all immediately give rise to the defiled mind of the desire realm.
Immediately after it, four minds can arise, that is, the four of its own realm. The other realms are not reasonable.

The other means the non-obscuring non-defined mind of the desire realm. This mind arises immediately after five, that is, the four of its own realm and the good mind of the form realm, because the mind of transformation of the desire realm arises from that.

Immediately after this [undefiled mind], seven minds can arise, namely the four of its own realm, and the two wholesome and defiled minds of the form realm. The mind of transformation of the desire realm still produces the wholesome [mind of the form realm]. In the state of rebirth, it produces the defiled [mind of the form realm].
And one of the formless realm. In the state of rebirth, this undefiled mind can produce the defiled [mind of the formless realm].
Immediately after the wholesome mind of the form realm, eleven minds can arise, excluding the undefiled and non-defined mind of the formless realm.
Immediately after this [wholesome mind], it arises from nine [minds], excluding the two defiled minds of the desire realm and excluding the undefiled and non-defined mind of the formless realm.
The defiled [mind] arises from eight [minds], excluding the two defiled [minds] of the desire realm and the learner and post-learner [minds].
Immediately after this [defiled mind], it can produce six minds, namely the three of its own realm, the wholesome, unwholesome, and defiled non-defined [minds] of the desire realm.
The non-defined [mind] arises from three [minds], namely only its own realm. The other [minds] do not have the principle of arising.
Immediately after this [non-defined mind], it can produce six minds, namely the three of its own realm, and the defiled [minds] of the desire and formless realms.
Nine minds arise immediately after wholesome minds in the formless realm, excluding wholesome minds of the desire realm and the two unwholesome minds of the desire realm.
Immediately after that, six minds arise, namely the three of its own realm, wholesome minds of the form realm, and learner and post-learner minds.
Immediately after the obscured [mind], seven minds arise, namely the three of its own realm, wholesome minds of the form realm, and the two defiled [minds] of the desire and form realms.
Immediately after that, seven minds arise, excluding the two defiled [minds] of the desire and form realms and the learner and post-learner minds.

The unobscured-indeterminate [mind] of the formless realm is explained like that of the form realm. Three minds arise immediately after it, namely the three of its own realm. The others are unreasonable.
Immediately after that, six minds arise, namely the three of its own realm and the two defiled [minds] of the desire and form realms.
The learner mind arises immediately after four minds, namely the learner mind itself and the wholesome minds of the three realms.
Immediately after that, five minds arise, namely the previous four minds and the post-learner [mind].
The remaining [minds] refer to the post-learner [mind], which arises immediately after five minds, namely the wholesome minds of the three realms and the two learner and post-learner [minds].
Immediately after this [mind of non-perception], four minds can arise, namely the wholesome minds of the three realms and the one mind of post-learner.
Having explained how the twelve minds give rise to each other,
how are these divided into twenty minds?
The verse says:
The twelve are divided into twenty, namely the wholesome minds of the three realms,
divided into acquired through practice and innate.
The unobstructed indeterminate of the desire realm is divided into four: the mind born of retribution, the mind of deportment, the mind of craftsmanship, and the mind of spiritual powers.
In the form realm, the mind of craftsmanship is excluded, the rest are as previously explained.
The treatise says:
The wholesome minds of the three realms are each divided into two types, namely those acquired through practice and those acquired through birth, because of their differences.
The unobstructed indeterminate of the desire realm is divided into four minds:
one born of retribution, two of deportment, three of craftsmanship, and four of spiritual powers.
The unobstructed indeterminate mind of the form realm is divided into three types, excluding the mind of craftsmanship, because there is no creation of various crafts in the upper realms.

These twelve are divided into twenty, that is, six kinds of good, and eight kinds of non-obscuring. There is no posture, etc., in the formless realm. The rest are the same as above, and therefore there are twenty.

The three kinds of non-obscuring minds such as the mind in a posture have as their objects form, smell, taste, and touch. The mind in a creative skill also has sound as an object. These three kinds of minds are only mental consciousness.
The preparatory stages of the minds in a posture and in a creative skill also have the four consciousnesses and the five consciousnesses.
Other masters say:
There is a mental consciousness attracted by the mind in a posture and by a creative skill that is able to have as its object the twelve sense spheres in their entirety.

As for these twenty minds arising from each other, first, among the eight kinds of minds in the realm of desire, a mind of applied thought is immediately followed by ten minds, that is, seven of its own realm, excluding the mind resulting from discrimination; a mind of applied thought of the realm of form; and the learnerâ€™s mind and the post-learnerâ€™s mind.

Furthermore, it arises immediately after eight: four of its own realm, two wholesome and two defiled, and two of the form realm, the wholesome of the stage of preliminary concentration and the obscured-neutral.
The wholesome mind obtained by birth immediately produces nine: seven of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal power, and the obscured-neutral minds of the form and formless realms.

Furthermore, it arises from eleven minds: seven of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal power, and two of the form realm, the wholesome of the stage of preliminary concentration and the obscured-neutral, and the learner and post-learner.
The two defiled minds immediately produce seven: seven of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal power.

Furthermore, they arise from fourteen minds: seven of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal power, and four of the form realm, excluding the wholesome of the stage of preliminary concentration and the mind of supernormal power, and three of the formless realm, excluding the wholesome.

The mind of posture immediately follows eight minds, that is, six of its own realm, excluding the mind of added effort and the mind of supernormal knowledge, and the obscured-neutral minds of the form and formless realms.
This mind of posture immediately follows seven minds, that is, the six of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal knowledge.
The mind of craftsmanship immediately follows six minds, that is, the six of its own realm, excluding the mind of added effort and the mind of supernormal knowledge.
This mind of craftsmanship immediately follows seven minds, that is, the six of its own realm, excluding the mind of supernormal knowledge.
The mind of supernormal knowledge immediately follows two minds, that is, the mind of supernormal knowledge of its own realm and the mind of added effort of the form realm.
This mind of supernormal knowledge also immediately follows two minds, that is, the two minds of its own realm and the form realm just mentioned.

Next, it is explained that among the six kinds of minds in the form realm, the mind of added effort immediately follows twelve minds, that is, the six of its own realm, the three of the desire realm - the minds of added effort, birth, and supernormal knowledge, and the mind of added effort of the formless realm, and the learner and post-learner minds.

It arises immediately after ten minds, that is, four of its own realm, excluding the mind of deportment and the mind arising from karmic maturation, and two of the desire realm, the wholesome and the obscured-neutral minds acquired through preparatory effort, and two of the formless realm, the obscured-neutral mind and the mind acquired through preparatory effort, and the learner's mind and the post-learner's mind.

The wholesome mind obtained by birth immediately produces eight minds, that is, five of its own realm, excluding the mind of spiritual powers, and the two unwholesome and obscured-neutral minds of the desire realm, and the obscured-neutral mind of the formless realm.

It arises immediately after five minds, that is, the five of its own realm, excluding the mind of spiritual powers.ğŸ”½The obscured-neutral mind immediately produces nine minds, that is, five of its own realm, excluding the mind of spiritual powers, and four of the desire realm, two wholesome and two defiled.

It arises immediately after eleven minds, that is, five of its own realm, excluding the mind of spiritual powers, and three of the desire realm, the wholesome mind obtained by birth, the mind of deportment, and the mind arising from karmic maturation, and three of the formless realm, excluding the wholesome mind acquired through preparatory effort.

Immediately after the mind of unmanifesting form of the form realm, seven minds arise. That is, the four of its own realm, excluding the mind of emanation and the mind of supernormal knowledge, and also the two of the desire realm, the unobscured non-determined mind and the obscured non-determined mind, and also the obscured non-determined mind of the formless realm.
Immediately after the mind of emanation of the form realm, two minds arise. That is, the two of its own realm, the mind of emanation and the mind of supernormal knowledge.

Immediately after the mind of emanation of the form realm, two minds arise. Among the twelve minds explained above, how many minds can be obtained when a certain mind is present?

Treatise:
When a defiled mind of the desire realm is present, six minds are obtained among the twelve minds, because they are obtained that have not been previously accomplished.
By continuing goodness through doubt and by falling away from the realms, the good mind of the desire realm is then said to be obtained.

By falling away from the passions and by falling away from the realms, the two minds of the desire realm are obtained: the unwholesome and the obscured. And one obscured mind of the form realm is obtained.
By falling away from the passions, one obscured mind of the formless realm is obtained, and the learner's mind is obtained.
Therefore it is said that six are obtained.
When a defiled mind of the form realm is present, six minds are also obtained among the twelve minds.
When one falls back from the realm of formlessness, one obtains the one undefiled mind of the realm of desire and the three of the realm of form.

When one falls back from the realm of form, one also obtains the defiled mind of the realm of form. When one falls back from the realm of form due to the arising of passions, one obtains the one obscured mind of the realm of formlessness and the mind of one still learning.
Therefore it is said that one obtains six.

When the defiled mind of the realm of formlessness is actually present, one obtains only two minds out of the twelve minds, because one obtains the defiled mind of that realm and the mind of one still learning due to falling back from the realm of formlessness due to the arising of passions. Therefore it is said that one obtains two.

When the good mind of the realm of form is actually present, one obtains three minds out of the twelve minds, namely, that good mind and the nondetermined minds of the realms of desire and form, because one advances.

When the mind of one still learning is actually present, one obtains four minds out of the twelve minds, namely, the mind of one still learning and the nondetermined minds of the realms of desire and form and the good mind of the realm of formlessness.
Because one first realizes entry into correct detachment from birth and death, and because the holy path causes one to become free from the passions of the realm of form.
The other minds are the defiled minds other than those just mentioned. It is not said that one obtains these minds when they are presently active.
You should understand that when these minds are presently active, only their own nature is obtained.
